last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27849213

If factory work was the best I could muster, sure I would. Because I understand that work isn't a hobby. Trying to make work something you like doesn't work out, because work is something you HAVE to do, week in, week out regardless of how you feel about doing it at that time.

All you end up doing when you try to find something you like is losing something you liked. Most jobs, even ones that might not seem immediately obvious to, consist of repetitive tasks day in, day out.

Work is the thing you do when you're not living your life in order to fund the tines when you are living your life. That's why the concept of work / life balance are separate things, because work is not life.

The goal for work is quite simple. Find a thing in the highest demand, you are most proficient at/suited to, with both the best starting wage and highest wage growth potential possible.

For example, just because you have the brains to be a lawyer doesn't mean you should be one if demand for more lawyers is low or you aren't naturally very good at arguing/logical thought.

You're supposed to be playing to your strengths so you increase your income as rapidly as possible whilst remaining on fixed expenses. ie. Income goes up, expenses do not.

Now if you're the kind of person where the answer to that equation is assembly worker in a factory line, no judgement the world needs things made. You might consider trying to upskill to a related trade, but if you lack the abilities to complete an apprenticeship then it is what it is.

End of the line, no matter what job you choose the grass will always seem greener on the other side, there will always be days/weeks/months/years you resent going into work, there will always be things you dislike about the job, it will always become tedious. Tedium at work just means we're no longer challenged by the work. When that happens we should either seek internal promotion or industry advancement through a new job at a competitor

Used to study Clinical psych. Not a doctor but, got a general good grasp:

I think youve already figured out willpower isnt actually really a thing. Youll basically react to your environment. 4chan is a huge distraction to you. Thats what youre going to do everyday when youve got ither shit to do.
Block it if you have to, or put some strong mental effort into not coming here. Break this addiction. Eliminate other distractions and what not.

Then in terms of new habits, helps to make a routine. If you can clear out a time frame, right after dinner or rigjt when you wake up, do so, and thats what time you do things you have to do. Itll be really hard at first, but if you keep on it, eventually itll be a compulsion. Like 6pm you feel you have ti be studying/painting etc.

One reason too is you might feel the tasks ate overwhelming. Beat that by breaking it down. For studying, dont read 30 pages. Read one. Then one more...
Break down projects into simple undaunting steps. Instead of "wite entire essay" think "Tuesday, find citation materials, wednesday, write structure plan" etc... things that are easy and sound doable that add up to a completed dissertation.

But 2 things I cant stress enough (i am literally talking to anyone reading this at all). Regularly, like once or twice a year, ask your doctor for a biochemistry test to check your levels and look for deficiencies, and 2, hydrate, proper diet, sleep enough.

You cant accomplish fuck all in this life in any wffective manner if you arent well slept hydrated and nourished.
>how do I eat good
Variety of fresh produce, whole grains, lean meats. Anything more is marketing. Just eat good food.

threads.com:
How can I begin truly loving myself?

Sounds tacky, but I realized the root of my problems is because starting from a young age I believed that I was worthless as a person. As I got older I began to suppress this feeling and fake confidence like so many people online suggest, but that has done nothing to actually improve my life. People have commented about how confident I seem and I notice people are more drawn to me the more I fake my persona but deep inside it just makes me feel more and more depressed because it’s as if I’m further validating that real me is worthless and people like what’s not me.

Anyways, I’ve been seeing a therapist for the past 2 months now and so far his approach to my issues are more CBT style and something I feel will not actually improve my life.

I’ve tried this method for the past year on my own and while it did help, it was more like I was continuing to fake it, and that core insecurity never left. After a triggering experience with a girl I dated, everything came back full force and it feels like I’m back to square one.

The reason why I’m so against CBT is because it doesn’t address the underlying issue which seems to be what is essentially pain caused by trauma. I want to process this pain and reassure myself by re experiencing the pain, but I’m not sure how as my memory is very foggy and my emotions have been numbed for quite some time no

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27845424
I was the same. Was bullied and badly treated in school by violent migrants who were in the same class as me but somehow 5 years older. At the same time lost friends. Retreated into gaming and addiction. Now in my 30s. Always hated myself. But secretly wanting more out of life, wanting to set things right. So I thought about what I would like to do with the rest of my life and found a fun answer. Since then I invested a lot of time and energy into this idea and I feel like my life is going somewhere and that I am doing well. So for the first time I started loving myself. I guess moral of the story, if you dont love yourself maybe you are not living up to your expectations. Sometimes the expectations are wrong however sometimes they are right

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27845424
One thing you can do is face your trauma. Sounds like you have memory issues so it will be difficult to re-discover the source of your trauma, but if you can figure it out I promise it will be worth the effort. Confronting the source of your trauma and learning how to be strong enough to move past it will work wonders for you.

Example: A girl approached me at a bar. 10/10 woman in terms of appearance. She invites me to visit her at work that weekend. When I do, she calls me a stalker and spreads this fake rumor about me to others. Months go by and I'm afraid to go out again, but when I finally do, I realize the rumor didn't go very far or people didn't believe it. Nothing fucking happened, therefore I had nothing to be afraid of. Guess what? That same girl is coming onto me again only now I'm strong and wise enough to know better and shun/reject her for the demon that she is.

Anyway, let's approach your original question. How do you begin truly loving yourself? You say you feel like a worthless person. Most people feel that way, I think. That's why so many resort to alcohol or drugs to fill the void in their soul. Even extremely talented people feel empty because they don't have anyone that is able to relate to them on their level. I think the key is to set your own goals and standards. If you can do that, then you have something to work toward. And it will take time, but you can certainly reach whatever goal you come up with if you make an honest effort toward it. It's not something that needs to be done by the end of the month, either. Go at your own pace; just a little bit every day will change you for the better in a year's time.

What would you like to be better at? Do you have any talents or hobbies? Is there a dream that you have neglected? Please share if you would like to continue, I'm very willing to help!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: These things take time and consistent effort. Im no therapist, but I'd suggest that you build up a sort of "portfolio" of "evidence" for why you SHOULD love yourself. Instead of just trying to say that you love yourself, prove that you deserve nothing but love, through achieving your goals.

I also have depression and anxiety (unrelated to the PMS lol). That shit isn't my fault. But it is my responsibility to act right. If mentally ill people don't get a pass to act like cunts, women with a hormone imbalance certainly don't get a pass lol.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27846572
Relax, OP. I got you.

You're 19, going back to college. Who you were in high school has no bearing on your college life; you're unlikely to run into any high school classmates. If you do, it'll be an occasional "hi" in passing.

You essentially have a clean slate. Try to make an active effort to socialize. You don't have to walk up to strangers in the cafeteria, what you need to do is be kind and friendly to your upcoming classmates. Let them know that you're chill and fun. You're all young; they will be receptive to your positive attitude and want you to be in their project groups or even spend time outside of class.

If you're into sports, join one at your school. If there are ANY and I mean ANY clubs or extracurricular activities that pique your interest, give them a chance. If they end up being a waste of time, you can stop attending those clubs and no one will judge you for it.

Another thing, and this can be tricky based on your school (it's something I struggled with for three years straight). If there are any girls in your classes that you feel even a modicum of attraction towards, make an effort to talk to her as often as you can. Even if you're not crazy about her at all, if some part of you says, "maybe..." then fucking go for it. I say this is tricky because you might have classes where you're not allowed to speak. If you say one word, your shithead professor will kick you out. That sort of thing. In that case, any opportunity you get to talk to your cute female classmate before or after class, fucking capitalize on it. I'll be thirty next month and I still regret not putting in more of an effort with the occasional college cutie which is why I'm telling you this.

I know you're anxious and afraid right now. You feel like you missed out and it's all your fault. It's okay to feel that way. I'm telling you that you still have plenty of time. I promise you still have plenty of chances and opportunities but it's up to you to capitalize on them.
